questions.text: Match the coenzyme and the group transferred by the coenzyme.
questions.solution:
Detailed Explanation

So Option B is appropriate match.

Key take away:

  • Coenzyme is a non protein part of enzyme
  • Low molecular weight organic substance

choices.text: Iodoacetate combines with -SH group of serine and inactivates enzyme
In non- competitive inhibition, Km value is lowered, Vmax is increased
In competitive inhibition, Km value is lowered. Vmax is unchanged
Disulfiram, a drug used in de-addiction treatment that non- competitively inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase for treatment in alcoholics

questions.text: Identify the correct sentence regarding enzyme inhibition
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Iodoacetate - inhibit enzymes having-SH group of cysteine in their active centers irreversibly. It is an example of non competitive inhibition.

Option B & Option C: In non- competitive inhibition, Km value remain same & Vmax is reduced.

In competitive inhibition, Km is increased (affinity is decreased), but Vmax is not changed.

Option D: Disulfiram, a drug used in de-addiction treatment of alcohol addiction. It non- competitively inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme.

Disulfiram works by inhibiting the enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH), which is involved in alcohol metabolism. Normally, ALDH converts acetaldehyde into acetate, which is harmless. When disulfiram blocks ALDH, acetaldehyde accumulates in the body after alcohol consumption, causing unpleasant symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, headache, and flushing. This creates a strong deterrent to drinking alcohol.

Key difference between Competitive inhibition and non competitive inhibition are:

questions.text: Which isoenzyme of ALP (alkaline phosphatase) is present in placenta?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Alpha-1 heat labile ALP is biliary ALP.

Option B: Alpha-1 heat stable ALP is Beta ALP.

Option C: Alpha-2 heat labile ALP is hepatic ALP.

Option D: Alpha-2 heat stable ALP is Placental ALP.

Detailed Explanation

  • Isoenzyme are multiple molecular forms of the enzyme catalyzing the same reaction
  • They are physically distinct forms of same enzyme
  • Differs in structure, mainly in their amino acid or carbohydrate composition
  • Produced in different tissues, but activity is same in all tissues
  • Different electrophoretic mobility
  • 3 important examples: LDH, CK, ALP

Isoenzyme of ALP based on electrophoretic mobility & their characteristics

Key take away

  • Alpha-1 region (Slowest): Placental and Regan isoenzymes.
  • Alpha-2 region (Slow): Liver isoenzyme.
  • Beta region (Faster): Bone isoenzyme.
  • Gamma region (Variable): Intestinal and kidney isoenzymes.
  • Pre-beta region: Atypical forms seen in some diseases.

questions.text: Identify the type of regulation of the enzyme given in the diagram
questions.solution: Inappropriate question & Options

questions.text: Match the enzyme classes and example.
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

IUBMB Classification of enzymes:

So Option D is most appropriate match.

Key take away

  • All dehydrogenase, oxidases and reductase are belonging to class I (Oxidoreductase)
  • All transferase, kinases are belonging to class II (Transferase)
  • All digestive enzyme are belonging to class III (Hydrolase)
  • Must remember: Aldolase are examples of lyase.
  • Recent advance:

7th class is Translocase: It helps in Translocation across membrane, examples are: Ornithine translocase, Carnitine acylcarnitine translocases

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism by which enzymes lower the activation energy of a reaction?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Enzymes lower the activation energy of a reaction primarily by stabilizing the transition state and providing an alternative reaction pathway with a lower energy barrier.

By using following mechanisms, enzymes reduce the energy barrier required for the reaction to proceed, thus increasing the reaction rate without being consumed in the process.

  1. Proximity and Orientation: Substrate binding & Active site arrangement
  2. Transition State Stabilization & Induced fit.
  3. Microenvironment Alteration like exclude water molecules, Create a charged environment to stabilize charged transition states, provide acidic or basic groups that can donate or accept protons, facilitating the breaking or forming of chemical bonds.
  4. Covalent Catalysis
  5. Strain and Distortion
  6. General Acid-Base Catalysis

Option B: Increasing substrate concentration will increase enzyme activity.

Option C: pH affects enzyme activity by altering charge. All enzyme has maximum activity at specific pH known as Optimum pH.

Option D: Temperature also affects enzyme activity. All enzyme has maximum activity at specific temperature known as Optimum temperature. Extreme temperature lead to denaturation of protein and enzyme, so stop its activity.

Key take away

  • Enzymes lower the activation energy of a reaction primarily by stabilizing the transition state.
  • pH, Temperature, substrate concentration, enzyme concentration, product concentration etc affect enzyme activity.

choices.text: The maximum velocity of the enzyme
The substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is half of Vmax
The affinity of the enzyme for the substrate

questions.text: In enzyme kinetics, what does the Michaelis constant (Km) represent?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Maximum velocity of enzyme is denoted as Vmax.

Option B: Km Represents the substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is at half of its maximum velocity (Vmax).

Option C: Km also gives an indication of the enzyme's affinity for its substrate:

Option D: Both B & C is correct option.

Detailed Explanation

The Michaelis constant (Km) is a key parameter in enzyme kinetics, particularly in the context of the Michaelis-Menten equation, which describes the rate of enzymatic reactions.

The Michaelis-Menten equation is

Where:

  • v is the reaction rate,
  • Vmax is the maximum rate,
  • [S] is the substrate concentration, and
  • Km is the Michaelis constant.

The units of Km are the same as the units of substrate concentration, typically moles per liter (M).

Key take away

  • Km Represents the substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is at half of its maximum velocity (Vmax).
  • It gives an indication of the enzyme's affinity for its substrate:
    • A low Km means the enzyme has high affinity for the substrate (it can reach half of Vmax at a low substrate concentration).
    • A high Km means the enzyme has low affinity for the substrate (it requires a higher substrate concentration to reach half of Vmax).

questions.text: Which type of inhibition is characterized by the inhibitor binding to the enzyme-substrate complex rather than the free enzyme?
questions.solution: Option wise explanation

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for breaking down hydrogen peroxide?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Key take away

  • Catalase and Peroxidase help to neutralize hydrogen peroxide, but catalase works independently, while peroxidase requires electron donors.
  • Superoxide Dismutase deals with superoxide radicals (O2-), converting them into less harmful substances like hydrogen peroxide.
  • Glutathione Peroxidase detoxifies hydrogen peroxide and organic peroxides using glutathione.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of an allosteric enzyme?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Hexokinase catalyzes the phosphorylation of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate (G6P) in the first step of glycolysis. When the levels of G6P build up, G6P acts as an inhibitor of hexokinase, reducing its activity. So regulated by feedback inhibition.

Option B: Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1): Key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis, Regulated by Allosteric regulation. Inhibited by ATP and citrate, activated by AMP, ADP, and fructose-2,6-bisphosphate.

Option C & Option D: Chymotrypsin & Trypsin both are digestive enzyme secreted by exocrine pancreas, help in digestion of protein. It regulated by Zymogen activation or Proteolytic cleavage.

Chymotrypsin and trypsin are synthesized and secreted as inactive precursors called zymogens (chymotrypsinogen and trypsinogen, respectively) to prevent them from digesting proteins inside the cells where they are produced.

Trypsinogen is activated into trypsin by the enzyme enteropeptidase, which is secreted by cells in the duodenum. Once active, trypsin can further activate more trypsinogen and also activate other zymogens, including Chymotrypsinogen into active chymotrypsin.

Detailed explanation about Allosteric enzymes

  1. Allosteric enzymes are regulated by molecules that bind to specific sites (allosteric sites) distinct from the active site. These molecules can be either activators or inhibitors.
  2. Binding of allosteric modulators induces a conformational change in the enzyme, affecting its activity. Activators stabilize the enzyme's active form, while inhibitors stabilize the inactive form.
  3. Many allosteric enzymes exhibit cooperative binding, similar to hemoglobin. This means that the binding of a substrate to one subunit affects the affinity of other subunits for the substrate (positive cooperativity). This often results in a sigmoidal (S-shaped) reaction rate curve, unlike the hyperbolic curve seen with non-allosteric enzymes.
  4. Allosteric enzymes play crucial roles in feedback inhibition, where the product of a metabolic pathway inhibits an enzyme involved earlier in the pathway. This helps maintain homeostasis by preventing overproduction of certain molecules.
  5. Allosteric enzymes are often multimeric, consisting of multiple subunits, so exhibits Quaternary structure.
  6. Allosteric enzymes do not follow Michaelis-Menten kinetics strictly. Instead, their activity is described using more complex models, such as the concerted (Monod-Wyman-Changeux) model or the sequential (Koshland-Némethy-Filmer) model.
  7. Examples of Allosteric Enzymes
  8. Aspartate Transcarbamoylase: Catalyzes the first step in pyrimidine biosynthesis, Inhibited by CTP (the end product of the pathway) and activated by ATP.
  9. Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1): Key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis, Inhibited by ATP and citrate, activated by AMP, ADP, and fructose-2,6-bisphosphate.
  10. Glycogen Phosphorylase: Breaks down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, Activated by AMP and inhibited by ATP and glucose-6-phosphate.
  11. Hemoglobin (while not an enzyme, it's an example of an allosteric protein): Binds and transports oxygen in blood, Oxygen binding is cooperative and influenced by H+, CO2, and 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (BPG).

Key take away

  • Allosteric enzymes are bind to allosteric sites, distinct from the active site of enzyme.
  • Many allosteric enzymes exhibit cooperative binding. This often results in a sigmoidal (S-shaped) reaction rate curve
  • Allosteric enzymes are often multimeric, so exhibits Quaternary structure.
  • Allosteric enzymes do not follow Michaelis-Menten kinetics strictly.
  • Examples of Allosteric Enzymes are: Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1), Aspartate Transcarbamoylase, Glycogen Phosphorylase & Hemoglobin

(Hemoglobin is not an enzyme, but it's an example of an allosteric protein)

questions.text: Which cofactor is required for the enzyme carboxylase?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Magnesium acts as a cofactor for many enzymes, particularly those involved in nucleic acid metabolism and phosphate transfer reactions. Examples are

  • DNA Polymerase: Requires magnesium for DNA replication and repair.
  • RNA Polymerase: Uses magnesium for RNA synthesis.
  • Hexokinase: Requires magnesium for the phosphorylation of glucose during glycolysis.
  • ATPases: These enzymes, which hydrolyze ATP, use magnesium to stabilize the ATP molecule during catalysis.
  • Phosphofructokinase (PFK): Involved in glycolysis, it requires magnesium to catalyze the phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate.

Option B: Iron (Fe²+ / Fe³+) is found in enzymes that are involved in electron transfer or redox reactions. Examples are:

  • Cytochrome oxidase: Part of the electron transport chain, it contains iron within the heme group and is essential for cellular respiration.
  • Catalase: Uses iron to break down hydrogen peroxide (H&sub2;O&sub2;) into water and oxygen.
  • Aconitase: An iron-sulfur enzyme involved in the citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle), catalyzing the isomerization of citrate to isocitrate.
  • Peroxidase: Contains iron and reduces peroxides (like H&sub2;O&sub2;).

Option C: Biotin acts as a coenzyme that carries activated carbon dioxide for carboxylation reactions. Examples are:

  • Pyruvate Carboxylase: Requires biotin to catalyze the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate in gluconeogenesis.
  • Acetyl-CoA Carboxylase: Involved in fatty acid synthesis, this enzyme uses biotin to add a carboxyl group to acetyl-CoA, forming malonyl-CoA.
  • Propionyl-CoA Carboxylase: Uses biotin to convert propionyl-CoA to methylmalonyl-CoA, which is important in the metabolism of certain amino acids and fatty acids.
  • Methylcrotonyl-CoA Carboxylase: Participates in the breakdown of leucine, requiring biotin as a cofactor.

Option D: Zinc is crucial for enzymes involved in hydrolysis and transcriptional regulation. Examples are:

  • Carbonic Anhydrase: Requires zinc to catalyze the reversible conversion of carbon dioxide and water to bicarbonate and protons.
  • Alcohol Dehydrogenase: Uses zinc to facilitate the conversion of alcohols to aldehydes or ketones.
  • Carboxypeptidase: A digestive enzyme that hydrolyzes peptide bonds, requiring zinc for its catalytic activity.
  • DNA Polymerase: Zinc is involved in maintaining the structural integrity of the enzyme during DNA replication.
  • Matrix Metalloproteinases (MMPs): Zinc-dependent enzymes involved in the breakdown of extracellular matrix proteins, important for tissue remodelling.

Key take away

A list of common cofactors and enzymes:

  • Magnesium: DNA Polymerase, RNA Polymerase, Hexokinase, Phosphofructokinase (PFK), ATPases
  • Iron: Cytochrome c Oxidase, Catalase, Aconitase, Peroxidases
  • Zinc: Carbonic Anhydrase, Alcohol Dehydrogenase, Carboxypeptidase, Matrix Metalloproteinases (MMPs), DNA Polymerase
  • Copper: Cytochrome c Oxidase, Superoxide Dismutase (SOD), Lysyl Oxidase
  • Manganese: Arginase, Superoxide Dismutase (SOD), Pyruvate Carboxylase

choices.text: It decreases both Vmax and Km

questions.text: In enzyme regulation, what is the effect of a competitive inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Vmax not changed in Competitive inhibition.

Option B: Competitive Inhibition increases Km value.

Option C: Both Vmax and Km decreases in uncompetitive inhibitors.

Option D: Noncompetitive Inhibition does not affect Km.

Detailed explanation about Enzyme Inhibitions & their effect on enzyme kinetics

Key take away

  • Competitive inhibitions increase Km, not affect Vmax
  • Noncompetitive inhibitions decrease Vmax, not affect Km
  • Uncompetitive inhibitions decrease Vmax & Km both

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes participates in the glycolytic pathway?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Glucose-6-Phosphatase Involved in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.

  • Function: Catalyzes the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose and inorganic phosphate.
  • Location: Found primarily in the liver and kidneys.
  • Regulation: Its activity helps maintain blood glucose levels during fasting or low-carbohydrate conditions.

Option B: Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) involved in Glycolysis.

  • Function: Catalyzes the phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate using ATP.
  • Regulation: Allosterically regulated; inhibited by ATP and citrate, activated by AMP and fructose-2,6-bisphosphate.
  • Importance: PFK-1 is a rate-limiting enzyme in glycolysis, controlling the flow of glucose through this pathway.

Option C: Pyruvate Carboxylase involved in gluconeogenesis and the citric acid cycle (anaplerotic reaction).

  • Function: Converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate using biotin as a cofactor.
  • Location: Found in mitochondria.
  • Regulation: Activated by acetyl-CoA, ensuring that oxaloacetate is produced when the citric acid cycle requires it.

Option D: Glycerol Kinase Involved in glycerol metabolism and gluconeogenesis.

  • Function: Phosphorylates glycerol to form glycerol-3-phosphate, which is an intermediate in triglyceride metabolism and glycolysis.
  • Location: Primarily found in the liver.
  • Importance: Converts glycerol, derived from triglycerides, into a form that can enter glycolysis or gluconeogenesis for energy production or glucose synthesis.

choices.text: Vmax is independent of enzyme concentration
Km is the maximum rate of the reaction
A lower Km indicates a lower affinity for the substrate
Competitive inhibitors increase the Vmax of a reaction

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding enzyme kinetics?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Vmax represents the maximum rate of an enzymatic reaction when the enzyme is saturated with substrate (independent of enzyme concentration). Vmax remains constant for a given enzyme concentration.

Option B: Km reflects the affinity of an enzyme for its substrate. A low Km indicates high affinity. A high Km suggests low affinity.

Km of any enzyme is substrate-specific and provides insight into enzyme efficiency under physiological conditions.

Option C: A low Km indicates high affinity for substrate & high Km suggests low affinity for substrate.

Option D: Competitive inhibitions increase Km, not affect Vmax. Noncompetitive inhibitions decrease Vmax, not affect Km. Uncompetitive inhibitions decrease Vmax & Km both

Detailed explanation about enzyme kinetics

Enzyme kinetics is the study of the rates of enzyme-catalyzed reactions, focusing on how the reaction rate changes concerning variables like substrate concentration, enzyme concentration, and environmental conditions (e.g., pH, temperature).

Michaelis-Menten equation describes the rate of enzymatic reactions as a function of substrate concentration:

v = reaction velocity (rate)

Vmax = maximum reaction rate when the enzyme is saturated with substrate

[S] = substrate concentration

Km = Michaelis constant, the substrate concentration at which reaction rate is half of Vmax

Lineweaver-Burk Plot

  • A double-reciprocal plot (1/v vs. 1/[S]) used to linearize the Michaelis-Menten equation for easier extraction of Km and Vmax values.
  • The slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot is Km/Vmax, and the intercepts on the axes provide values for 1/Vmax and -1/Km.

Factors Affecting Enzyme Kinetics

  • Temperature: Enzyme activity generally increases with temperature up to a point, after which denaturation occurs.
  • pH: Each enzyme has an optimal pH range where it functions best.
  • Enzyme concentration: Increasing enzyme concentration will increase the reaction rate, provided there is enough substrate.
  • Inhibitors: Competitive inhibitors increase apparent Km (since they compete for the active site), while non-competitive inhibitors decrease Vmax without affecting Km.

Key take away

  • Km reflects the affinity of an enzyme for its substrate.
  • A low Km indicates high affinity. A high Km suggests low affinity.
  • Vmax remains constant for a given enzyme concentration.

questions.text: What is the primary clinical use of the enzyme asparaginase?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Insulin and oral hypoglycemic drugs are used in treatment of Diabetes. Asparaginase has no role.

Option B: Asparaginase is an enzyme primarily used in medical settings to treat certain types of cancer, especially acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Asparaginase works by catalyzing the conversion of the amino acid asparagine into aspartic acid and ammonia. Many cancer cells, particularly leukemia cells, are unable to synthesize sufficient asparagine on their own and depend on external sources of the amino acid. So Asparaginase depletes asparagine levels in the bloodstream, starving cancer cells of this essential nutrient and inhibiting their ability to grow and divide, while normal cells (which can produce asparagine) are less affected.

Option C: Liver function test like ALT, AST, ALP, Bilirubin total, direct and indirect, protein total, albumin, Prothrombin time etc used to diagnose liver diseases.

Option D: Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder that affects the lungs, digestive system, and other organs due to the production of thick and sticky mucus. The management of CF focuses on improving quality of life, preventing complications, and slowing disease progression. It requires a multidisciplinary approach involving medications, therapies, nutritional support, and infection control. Here asparaginase has no role in CF management.

Key therapeutic uses of enzymes:

  • Asparaginase: Treats acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) by depleting asparagine, a nutrient essential for cancer cell growth.
  • Streptokinase/Alteplase (tPA): Used in thrombolytic therapy to dissolve blood clots in conditions like myocardial infarction and stroke.
  • Lactase: Treats Lactose intolerance by breaking down lactose in dairy products.
  • Pancreatic Enzymes (Lipase, Amylase, Protease): Used in pancreatic insufficiency (e.g., cystic fibrosis, chronic pancreatitis) to aid digestion.
  • Pepsin/Papain: Helps in digestive enzyme supplements for protein digestion disorders.
  • Hyaluronidase: Facilitates drug absorption by breaking down hyaluronic acid in connective tissues; also used in cosmetic surgery.
  • Collagenase: Promotes wound healing by breaking down collagen in necrotic tissue, used in chronic ulcers and burns.

questions.text: Which enzyme is often elevated in cases of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A & Option B: Both amylase and lipase are routinely measured in blood tests for the diagnosis and monitoring of acute pancreatitis.

Lipase being the more specific marker increased only in pancreatic disorders, whereas amylase increased in pancreatic disorders as well as also in salivary gland disorders.

Option D: Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is an enzyme found in many tissues throughout the body, and elevated levels in the blood can indicate tissue damage or disease.

Increased LDH can be associated with various conditions, including Myocardial infarction (heart attack), Liver disease like hepatitis, cirrhosis, or liver cancer, muscle injury, hemolytic anemia, cancer like lymphomas, leukemias, and metastatic cancers, pulmonary embolism and pneumonia can cause elevated LDH due to lung tissue damage, infections etc. LDH is a non-specific marker, so elevated levels are often considered alongside other clinical findings to diagnose specific conditions.

So Option C is correct answer.

Detailed explanation about diagnostic uses of enzymes:

Key take away

  • Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT), Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST) - Increased in hepatitis
  • Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP) - Nonspecific, Increased in obstructive jaundice, bone diseases
  • Amylase, Lipase - Increased in pancreatitis
  • Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase (GGT) - Increased in Alcoholic liver disease
  • Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH) - Nonspecific, Increased in tissue injury
  • Creatinine kinase - Increased in Muscle injury
  • CKMB, Troponins - Increased in Heart attack

questions.text: What is the function of enzyme replacement therapy in patients with Gaucher's disease?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Deficient hormone replaced in endocrine hypo functioning diseases.

Option B: Enzyme replacement therapy replaces deficiency enzymes.

Option C: Antibiotics used to treat infections.

Option D: Oral hypoglycemic agents like metformin, Thiazolidinediones, GLP-1 Receptor Agonists, SGLT2 Inhibitors, DPP-4 Inhibitors are used to improve insulin sensitivity in type 2 DM.

Detailed Explanation about Gaucher's disease

  • Genetic disorder
  • Caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.
  • The lack of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of a fatty substance called glucosylceramide (or glucocerebroside) within cells, particularly in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow. This accumulation causes the characteristic symptoms of the disease, such as enlarged organs, anemia, bone pain, and skeletal abnormalities.
  • Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) provides patients with a synthetic version of the deficient enzyme (glucocerebrosidase) to help break down the accumulated glucosylceramide.
  • ERT is most effective in treating Type 1 Gaucher disease, which primarily affects the liver, spleen, and bones. It has less impact on Type 2 and Type 3, which involve severe neurological symptoms, as the enzyme cannot cross the blood-brain barrier.
  • Common drugs used in ERT for Gaucher's disease include imiglucerase (Cerezyme), velaglucerase alfa (VPRIV), and taliglucerase alfa (Elelyso).

choices.text: To evaluate tissue hypoxia and cell damage

questions.text: What is the primary use of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) as a diagnostic enzyme?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Tests to assess kidney function include Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR), Serum Creatinine, Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN), Urinalysis, and Urine Albumin-to-Creatinine Ratio (UACR). Additional tests are Creatinine Clearance, Electrolyte Panel, and Cystatin C. Imaging studies like renal ultrasound and kidney biopsy may also be used.

Option B: The primary use of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) as a diagnostic enzyme is to detect tissue damage and cellular injury. Elevated LDH levels in the blood can indicate damage to various tissues, including the heart (myocardial infarction), liver, kidneys, muscles, lungs, and red blood cells (hemolysis). It is often used in the diagnosis and monitoring of conditions like heart attack, liver disease, hemolytic anemia, certain cancers, and lung diseases.

LDH also involved in anerobic glycolysis, so used to evaluate tissue hypoxia.

Option C: Commonly used tests to diagnose diabetes includes:

  • Fasting Blood Glucose (FBG) test, which measures blood sugar after an overnight fast
  • Postprandial 2 hours Blood Glucose (PP2BG), which measures blood sugar 2 hours after meal
  • Random Blood Glucose test can be used for immediate diagnosis.
  • Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT), which checks blood sugar levels before and after consuming glucose.
  • Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) test reflects average blood sugar over the past 3 months.

Option D: Tests used to monitor cholesterol levels include Lipid profile, which measures: Total Cholesterol, Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL) often referred to as "bad" cholesterol, High-Density Lipoprotein (HDL), known as "good" cholesterol and Triglycerides.

These tests assess cardiovascular risk and monitor lipid management.

Key take away

  • Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) test reflects average blood sugar over the past 3 months, used for monitoring of DM patients.
  • Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL) is bad cholesterol. It its higher - risk of atherosclerosis and heart attack is more, if its level is low - risk is low. So its level is directly proportionate to risk of atherosclerosis and heart attack.
  • High-Density Lipoprotein (HDL), known as "good" cholesterol. It its higher - risk of atherosclerosis and heart attack is less, if its level is low - risk is high. So its level is inversely proportionate to risk of atherosclerosis and heart attack.

questions.text: Which enzyme is involved in the management of thrombotic events by converting plasminogen to plasmin?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Urokinase is an enzyme that promotes the breakdown of blood clots by converting plasminogen into plasmin, which then degrades fibrin, the main component of clots. This fibrinolytic action helps dissolve clots in blood vessels. It is used in Pulmonary embolism, Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) etc to dissolve clots.

Option B: Lipase is an enzyme responsible for breaking down fats (lipids) into fatty acids and glycerol during digestion. It is produced mainly by the pancreas, though smaller amounts are produced in the mouth (saliva), stomach & intestine.

Elevated levels of lipase in the blood are used to diagnose and monitor pancreatitis (inflammation of the pancreas) and other pancreatic disorders.

Option C: Creatine kinase (CK), also known as creatine phosphokinase (CPK), is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in energy production by catalysing the conversion of creatine and ATP into phosphocreatine and ADP, a process important for muscle contraction.

CK levels are elevated in conditions like myocardial infarction (heart attack), rhabdomyolysis, muscular dystrophy, and other muscle injuries. CK total level is often used to diagnose and monitor muscle injury.

3 Isoenzymes of CK:

  • CK-MB: Found primarily in the heart, elevated after heart damage, commonly used in diagnosis and monitoring of heart attack
  • CK-MM: Found mainly in skeletal muscles.
  • CK-BB: Present mostly in the brain.

Option D: Thrombin is a key enzyme in the blood clotting process, responsible for converting fibrinogen into fibrin, which forms the structural framework of a blood clot. Thrombin also activates platelets and other clotting factors, promoting further clot formation.

Thrombin is used clinically as a topical agent to control bleeding during surgeries or injuries.

Anticoagulant Therapy: Drugs like direct thrombin inhibitors (e.g., dabigatran) are used to prevent excessive clot formation in conditions such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and atrial fibrillation.

Key take away

  • Urokinase promotes breakdown of blood clots by converting plasminogen into plasmin, used in DVT & Pulmonary embolism
  • Thrombin converts fibrinogen into fibrin, so help in blood clotting
  • Lipase is help in fat digestion, produced by pancreas (mainly), saliva, stomach, intestine. Lipase level in blood increased during pancreatitis.
  • Creatine kinase (CK), also known as creatine phosphokinase (CPK), plays role in energy production.

choices.text: Enzymes that catalyze the same reaction but have different structures
Enzymes that catalyze different reactions but have similar structures
Enzymes that function at different pH levels
Enzymes that are found in different cellular compartments

questions.text: What are isoenzymes?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Isoenzymes are those enzymes that catalyze the same reaction but have different structures.

Option B: They are enzymes that catalyze same reaction but have different structures.

Option C: No different in pH in different isoenzymes.

Option D: Isoenzymes are often found in specific tissues, allowing for targeted diagnostic use (e.g., CK-MB in the heart, CK-MM in skeletal muscle). Not in different cellular compartments.

Key take away

  • Isoenzyme are multiple molecular forms of the enzyme catalyzing the same reaction
  • Catalyze same reaction
  • Differs in structure, mainly in their amino acid or carbohydrate composition
  • Produced in different tissues, but activity is same in all tissues
  • Different electrophoretic mobility
  • 3 important examples: LDH, CK, ALP

choices.text: They have identical amino acid sequences
They are produced in specific tissues and may have different regulatory properties

questions.text: What distinguishes tissue-specific isoenzymes from other enzymes?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: All enzymes and isoenzymes are heat labile,

Option B: Isoenzymes are different in structure, mainly in their amino acid or carbohydrate composition.

Option C: Isoenzyme catalyzes same reaction, so have same substrate.

Option D: Isoenzymes are produced in different tissues

Key take away

  • Isoenzyme are multiple molecular forms of the enzyme catalyzing the same reaction
  • Catalyze same reaction
  • Differs in structure, mainly in their amino acid or carbohydrate composition
  • Produced in different tissues, but activity is same in all tissues
  • Different electrophoretic mobility
  • 3 important examples: LDH, CK, ALP

choices.text: They increase the Km of the enzyme
They can bind to both the free enzyme and the enzyme-substrate complex

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about non-competitive inhibitors?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Competitive inhibitions increase Km, not affect Vmax.

Option B: Non-competitive Inhibitors can can bind to both the free enzyme and the enzyme-substrate complex.

Option C: Noncompetitive inhibitions decrease Vmax, not affect Km.

So Option D is correct option.

Key take away about Non-competitive Inhibition

  • Inhibitor binds to an allosteric site, not the active site.
  • Effect on Km: No change
  • Effect on Vmax: Decreases
  • Typically reversible, but can also be irreversible.
  • Increasing substrate has do not overcome inhibition.
  • Examples: Heavy metals like silver or lead.

choices.text: Has no effect on Vmax or Km

questions.text: What is the effect of an uncompetitive inhibitor on the enzyme kinetics?
questions.solution:
Effect of inhibition on enzyme kinetics

Key take away

  • Competitive inhibitions increase Km, not affect Vmax
  • Noncompetitive inhibitions decrease Vmax, not affect Km
  • Uncompetitive inhibitions decrease Vmax & Km both

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts as a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Methotrexate is a competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).

DHFR is an enzyme that reduces dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, a cofactor necessary for the synthesis of nucleotides (purines and thymidylate) and DNA.

Inhibiting DHFR prevents the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate, thus disrupting DNA replication and cell division, particularly in rapidly dividing cells such as cancer cells.

Methotrexate is used in the treatment of cancer, autoimmune diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis), and ectopic pregnancies.

Option B: Aspirin acts as an irreversible inhibitor of cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2) enzymes. These enzymes are involved in the production of prostaglandins and thromboxanes, which are mediators of inflammation and platelet aggregation.

Aspirin is commonly used as an anti-inflammatory, antipyretic (fever reducer), analgesic (pain reliever), and antiplatelet agent (for preventing blood clots).

Option C: Penicillin inhibits bacterial transpeptidase enzymes, which are involved in the synthesis of peptidoglycan, an essential component of bacterial cell walls. By inhibiting transpeptidase, penicillin causes bacterial cell wall synthesis to fail, leading to bacterial cell lysis and death.

Penicillin and its derivatives are used to treat bacterial infections, particularly those caused by Gram-positive bacteria.

Option D: Statins are competitive inhibitors of HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in the synthesis of cholesterol.

Statins are widely used to lower cholesterol levels in patients with hypercholesterolemia and to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events such as heart attacks and strokes.

Key take away

  • Methotrexate - competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase.
  • Aspirin inhibits COX enzymes (irreversible inhibition).
  • Penicillin inhibits bacterial transpeptidase.
  • Statins - competitive inhibitor of HMG-CoA reductase.

choices.text: It decreases the Km and increases the Vmax
It decreases both Km and Vmax
It increases the Km but does not change Vmax
It does not affect Km or Vmax

questions.text: In enzyme kinetics, what is the effect of increasing the concentration of a competitive inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: In competitive inhibition, Km increases because the inhibitor competes with the substrate for the active site, making it harder for the substrate to bind. However, Vmax remains unchanged because at high substrate concentrations, the enzyme can still reach its maximum rate by outcompeting the inhibitor.

Option B: In competitive inhibition, Km increases (not decreases), and Vmax remains the same. A decrease in both Km and Vmax would indicate a different type of inhibition, such as uncompetitive inhibition, where the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex and not the free enzyme.

Option C: In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for the active site, requiring a higher substrate concentration to reach half the maximum velocity, which increases the apparent Km. However, since the inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration, Vmax remains unchanged.

Option D: In competitive inhibition, the Km increases due to the need for more substrate to compete with the inhibitor. If the inhibitor had no effect on either Km or Vmax, it would imply that the inhibitor is not interacting with the enzyme or substrate in a significant way.

Key take away

  • Competitive inhibitions increase Km, not affect Vmax
  • Noncompetitive inhibitions decrease Vmax, not affect Km
  • Uncompetitive inhibitions decrease Vmax & Km both
